repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
When a terminal application running inside the terminal emulator sets the cursor shape or blink status of the cursor, update the cursor in the parent terminal to match.

This removes the "virtual cursor" that has been in use by the terminal emulator since the beginning. The original rationale for using the virtual cursor was to avoid having to support additional UI methods to change the cursor color for other (non-TUI) UIs, instead relying on the TermCursor and TermCursorNC highlight groups.

The TermCursor highlight group is now used in the default `'guicursor'` value, which has a new entry for Terminal mode. However, the TermCursorNC highlight group is no longer supported: since terminal windows now use the real cursor, when the window is not focused there is no cursor displayed in the window at all, so there is nothing to highlight. Users can still use the `StatusLineTermNC` highlight group to differentiate non-focused terminal windows.

BREAKING CHANGE: The TermCursorNC highlight group is no longer supported.

Fixes #3681.
Fixes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/20325.

comment_data.body:
I fixed `TermCursor`, so we won't regress that in this PR (it was easy, just set it in `'guicursor'` and everything magically worked).

`TermCursorNC` will no longer be supported at all though. This is not a temporary regression, but a permanent change. When the terminal window doesn't have focus, there is simply no cursor, so there's no highlight group to apply. We still have `StatusLineTermNC` though.

I'll add this to `news.txt` and `deprecated.txt`.

This is mentioned in the PR description:

>There is one bug I'm chasing down where exiting and then re-entering Terminal mode causes a disagreement in cursor position between Nvim and the terminal. But otherwise it seems to be working ok.

I was able to solve the cursor issue so this is fully working now. I also implemented cursor hiding, so if an application in the terminal emulator hides the cursor it will be hidden in Nvim too.

Because we are using the real cursor now and not the virtual cursor, I had to update any test that uses the terminal cursor in the expected screen output... which was a lot of them. There are some tests that fail now because of TermCursor. I've marked those as `pending` for now.

I still have issues when navigating in the current line using the cursors (`set -o emacs`) or `e` and `b` (`set -o vi`). 

```bash
nvim --clean
:terminal<cr>
bash --noprofile --norc
set -o vi
echo -e '\e[5 q'
```
After this, if I press `<esc>`, and then `k` and then `e`, I notice the cursor is not redrawn at the end of the first word (`|echo -e '\e[5 q'`). If I click again `e` then the cursor gets redrawn at the end of the first word (`ech|o -e '\e [5 q'`), but if I click `x` (to delete the character at the cursor), I notice that the dash gets deleted (`echo |e '\e [5 q'`). 

Another test: If I press `<esc>` and then `k` and then `e` and again `e`, the cursor is redrawn at the end of the first word (`ech|o -e '\e [5 q'`) instead of after it. If I unfocus the xterm window and then re-focus it, the cursor will get redrawn in the normal position (`echo |-e '\e [5 q'`). 

Same goes also for `set -o emacs` if I navigate with the cursors.

I've tested some more and I've found some more corner cases that don't work properly. I've tried to stress it a little with software demanding a lot from the tui. There is software which will hide the cursor completely, like [vifm](https://github.com/vifm/vifm), [btop](https://github.com/aristocratos/btop) or nmtui.
So, taking the previous lua mapping file (/tmp/mappings.lua):

```lua
vim.api.nvim_set_keymap('t', '<f1>', '', {
    callback = function()
        vim.api.nvim_command('tabn 1')
        vim.api.nvim_command('startinsert')
    end
})

vim.api.nvim_set_keymap('t', '<f2>', '', {
    callback = function()
        vim.api.nvim_command('tabn 2')
        vim.api.nvim_command('startinsert')
    end
})
```
then, starting with a new terminal:

```
nvim --clean<cr>
:luafile /tmp/mappings.lua<cr>
:terminal<cr>i
vifm<cr> # or btop, or nmtui
# notice the cursor is hidden completely now
<C-\><C-n>
:tabnew<cr>
:terminal<cr>i #the cursor is a line in the second terminal
<f1>
```

At this moment, in the first tab, the cursor should still be hidden, but it's visible as the line. Even if I go through the normal mode and back to terminal mode (`<C-\><C-n>i`), the cursor remains visible. Also, restarting `vifm` (or `btop`, or `nmtui`), the cursor is still visible.

And another, even more corner case, represents `nvim` itself ran inside the terminal (since it stresses the most that terminal). 

```
nvim --clean<cr>
:terminal<cr>
nvim --clean<cr>
i<tab>
```
Now, the cursor should be displayed at 8 spaces. The cursor is still at the beginning of the row. However, if I type something (like `x`), then the cursor will be displayed in the proper position (8 spaces from left) and the `x` appears in the proper place. It seems that the cursor is just not updated at the proper position after the tab.

Same goes with the spaces: 

```
nvim --clean<cr>
:terminal<cr>i
nvim --clean<cr>
i<space><space><space><space>
```
The cursor is still at the beginning of the line. However, if I type in something other than space or tab, like `x`, then the `x` will be displayed in the proper position. It just seems that the cursor is not updated.

Same is valid also for `vim`: 

```
nvim --clean<cr>
:terminal<cr>
vim --clean<cr>
i<tab>
```
The cursor is not displayed at 8 characters, but at the beginning of the line. Typing `x`, it will be displayed at the proper position and the cursor updated in the proper position.

Related with the previous bug, I've noticed that if the actions are in the reverse order (first an empty terminal tab and then vifm), then the cursor is lost. 

Given the mapping file (/tmp/mappings.lua):

```lua
vim.api.nvim_set_keymap('t', '<f1>', '', {
    callback = function()
        vim.api.nvim_command('tabn 1')
        vim.api.nvim_command('startinsert')
    end
})


vim.api.nvim_set_keymap('t', '<f2>', '', {
    callback = function()
        vim.api.nvim_command('tabn 2')
        vim.api.nvim_command('startinsert')
    end
})
```

then, in a new terminal: 

```
nvim --clean<cr>
:luafile /tmp/mappings.lua<cr>
:terminal<cr>i
<C-\><C-n>
:tabnew<cr>
:terminal<cr> # the line cursor is visible now
vifm<cr> # there is no cursor now
<f1> # still no cursor in the first tab
<C-\><C-n>i # still no cursor
```

It appears that there is no way to get back the cursor, after this. Even by doing `echo -e '\e[5 q'` or `reset` will not bring back the cursor. Maybe this helps.

I believe I've fixed the issues with cursor visibility (and I've added tests for those as well).

I can repro your issue with the nested `nvim` instance as well. I'm not sure exactly what's happening there so I'll have to dig into that a bit more.
